author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Tamil Nadu Open University has become eligible to apply for Central government research grants following its inclusion under Section 12 (B) of the University Grants Commission (UGC) Act.

The institution is the fifth among open universities in the country to receive the status. Already Bhopal, Nashik, Kota and Hyderabad open universities have the 12B status.

The UGC has advised the TNOU to apply to the National Assessment and Accreditation Council for accreditation.

TNOU Vice-Chancellor Chandrakantha Jeyabalan told journalists here on Thursday that the university had fulfilled all the criteria, including the required infrastructure.

As part of the UGC’s mandate, the university had set up centres in Chennai, Madurai, Dharmapuri and Coimbatore. An extent of five acres had been identified in Madurai to set up a community college. The University had written to district collectors in Chennai, Madurai, Dharmapuri and Coimbatore to identify suitable plots for establishing the centres.

New courses

The 13-year-old University is now awaiting inspection by the National Council for Teacher Education to enable it launch undergraduate and postgraduate courses in education. With the Council’s approval the university proposes to launch full-time B Ed and M Ed courses, which are expected to draw around 1,500 students. Courses such as B Sc Ed and BA Ed, which students can join after Class XII, will also be introduced.

A course for special educators with 250 seats is proposed to be launched with the approval of Rehabilitation Council of India.

The university is now eligible to conduct special assistance programmes, introduce new faculty position for five years and receive grants to build facilities such as research lab, auditorium, library, network facilities, women’s hostel and guest house.

It will also be able to set up more study centres and a day care centre for children of the faculty.

title: TNOU eligible to apply for Central research grants
